Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2009 07:23PM NewportLori wrote: Hi All!  London-Virginia asked me to stop by this thread and share my experiences with using Penguin Cold Caps to during TC chemo to save my hair.  There are two theads here discussing them.  If you go to my profile, you can find the threads and see my recent posts.  I had my third TC infusion yesterday and I still have a full covering of hair.  I rent the caps from the UK company, but they are shipped from a facility in California (I was able to pick mine up).  The website for the company is: http://www.msc-worldwide.com/.  Another breast cancer patient I met via these boards helps we with the application of the caps and I will help her if she elects chemo. The really great news is that since I am getting neoadjuvant chemo (before surgery), we are able to observe the response on my 3 tumors.  10 days after my second tx, I had an MRI which reported that my two smaller tumors were no longer seen (one of which was 1.6 cm) and the largest had shrunk to only 35% of it's original volume.  I was told this was an unusually positive response this early to the TC regimen (although it is seen on TCH for HER2+ patients). Feel free to PM me for more information or if you would like my telephone number. Best wishes to all of you just starting this chemo journey!  I've had 3 of my 6 infusions and am holding up well.  My anti-nausea meds have worked extremely well and Claritin and ibuprofen have kept bone pain at bay from the Neulasta injection (which I give to myself in my stomach -- it's no big deal if you're afraid).  My most pervasive SEs are fatigue and taste changes (plain water tastes like saline solution - yuck!).  My tongue felt all swollen and numb for a time after my first tx, but I used Biotene mouthwash and it helped.  I still had taste changes with each tx, which never totally go away before the next tx, but no more tongue symptoms. I am extremely grateful that I also still have hair, but was willing to lose it if need be as I am at a high risk for mets.  I had a wig and scarves on standby if the caps didn't work. Again best wishes to all my unknown BC sisters here.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo September 2009 krcll sanaisa

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 05:57PM NewportLori wrote: I am also doing neoadjuvant chemo and had my first tx on Fri 7/24/09.  I first researched it after my dx to see if my original large tumor could be shrunk to allow a lumpectomy.  However MRI found 2 more smaller tumors, making mastectomy necessary I'm told. In talking to my onc, neoadjuvant made sense anyway as I am borderline stage III.  Total mass of the 3 tumors was 7cm and, although no obvious lymph involvement was found via imaging, path report stated suspicion of it.  If I were confirmed stage III, neoadjuvant would be the preferred tx.  He explained that it is delivered through a still intact vascular system and that we can observe the effect of the chemo on the actual tumor(s).  Since there didn't seem to be a disadvantage to doing it, I elected to try. I'm hoping that it erradicates my tumors and any current unknown lymph involvement, potentially allowing me to skip rads.  It's good to see the postive results the rest of you have had.
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo Beth7 kae_md99

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2009 02:55AM NewportLori wrote:
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo Beth7 kae_md99

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 05:39PM - edited Dec 1, 2009 06:20PM by NewportLori Laurie, I live alone and had no other person to clean the litter box.  My doctor recommended using latex gloves and a face mask for cleaning the litter box.  Because I knew I was going to wash my hands immediately, I never used the gloves.  I did use a face mask for the first few chemo cycles, but when I realized that the Nuelasta shots I gave myself the day after each chemo were preventing dramatic drops in WBC, I stopped doing even that and never got a complication related to bacteria.
Posts.Title: pets and chemo hopefullady NewportLori

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 03:41PM - edited Dec 1, 2009 04:56PM by NewportLori I made it through 6 TC cycles behaving completely normally (cuddling, etc.) with my cat, who is a large, young, stictly indoors, male Bengal.  I was careful to always wash my hands after cleaning his litter box, which is something I usually did anyway.  He also enjoyed joining me on afternoon naps during chemo crash days. The biggest problem I had is that he sometimes likes to nip me (lite bite) as a show of affection when I am stroking him.  Prior to chemo, these nips were harmless.  However, my skin became so sensitive during chemo that his nips sometimes left scratches or marks that took many days to resolve.  I took him in as a foster cat when his previous owner, a 32 year old woman, died and he was alone with her body for 3 days before she was found.  The police who found the woman had animal control take him to a shelter where he stayed for 2 days before someone picked him up,  She had adopted him from a shelter only 5 months earlier.  Although he had clearly been someone's pet previously (very socialized), he was found as a stray in an apartment complex and taken to a shelter where he stayed for nearly 2 months before being adopted.  When he came to stay with me as a foster cat in early February 2009, he was very frightened, confused and shut down from his multiple ordeals.  I was determined to help him and started with love blinks (slow eye blinks when gazing at him).  He responded immediately and approached me for affection.  He reacted as though he was happy that I could communicate with him in cat language.  After that, he continued to come out of his shell and would bring teaser wands to me in a request for play.  He would also retrieve/fetch the wands and other toys that were tossed.  As he grew in trust, he began to sleep next to me and demonstrated all kinds of behaviors and vocalizations to communicate with me. When I was diagnosed with BC in May 2009, I wasn't sure I should keep him - after all, he was just a foster cat and by then seemed rehabilitated.  I placed an ad on craigslist looking to rehome him and had many interested parties.  However, one woman wrote to me and linked to an article about how pets, especially cats, can be of great benefit emotionally when going through cancer treatment.  It was then I decided to keep him.  He's been a great support through my chemo and I love him dearly.
Posts.Title: pets and chemo hopefullady NewportLori

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2009 03:54PM NewportLori wrote: Maggie, Tigger and I still do love blinks almost daily to each other.  He is very intelligent and seems to know that I am trying to speak his language.  We also yawn at each other, something he also seems to enjoy. Best wishes!
Posts.Title: pets and chemo hopefullady NewportLori

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2009 08:26PM NewportLori wrote: 51, but have 3 tumors, one of which is large (5 cm, 1.6 cm and .5 cm), so I may have had BC for quite a while.  I have radiographically dense breasts and even my diagnostic mammo showed the main turmor merely as distortion.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 09:37PM NewportLori wrote: Thank you for responding Cheryl.  How was the TC regimen?  Did you lose all of your hair (including eyelashes and eyebrows)?  Did you you lose or have any major impact on your fingernails or toenails?  Lori
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and don't know how to navigate this site NewportLori xpectmiracles

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 10:16PM - edited Jul 1, 2009 10:28PM by NewportLori Hi Lisa: So good to get your response as you have many similar disease aspects to mine, including a large tumor.  My 3 tumors combined measure over 7 cm.  Even before the MRI showed multi-focal disease, my main tumor alone was so large in comparison to my barely B-cup breast size that a lumpectomy first was not an option for me -- there wouldn't have been much left.  Although my sentinel nodes have not yet been removed, the biopsy path report stated suspicion of node involvement.  If that's the case, I will also need rad tx, which I'm told would make reconstruction with implants more difficult.  The plastic surgeon said she recommends a flap reconstruction after rad tx but I don't have sufficient abdomial fat for the complete reconstruction, so would still need supplemental implants.  I carry my fat all over my body and my limbs probably have more fat than my belly.  I'm hoping that the neoadjuvant TC regimen will assure that my nodes (even if they are positive now) will be found negative when I eventually have surgery.  That might allow me to avoid rad tx and have a better outcome with reconstruction since I could simply use implants. Glad to hear that you already have a full head of hair!  I read that Taxotere has a 6% occurence of permanent hair loss (low but still scary). UCLA is very well respected in cancer research and treatment.  It does give me some degree of assurance that you were given the same protocol of 6 TC cycles.  Thanks again!!!
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and don't know how to navigate this site NewportLori xpectmiracles

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2009 12:10PM NewportLori wrote: I was on TC and had Rxs for Emend, Ativan and Compazine.  I took first dose of Emend on the day of chemo and next two days (but lower doses).  Ativan was in chemo pre-meds so not needed until day 2, but took for next 2 days as I did with Compazine.  On the day of my 6th chemo, I had misplaced my Emend.  Onc's office gave me the lower dose I usually take on day 2-3 and still no nausea. They said that many patients do well on just Ativan and Compazine.  However, I never had chemo without at least the minimum dose of Emend, so can't comment on that.
Posts.Title: Ativan/Compazine instead of Emend? Ang7 kayakgirl

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 10:57PM - edited Jul 1, 2009 11:00PM by NewportLori Hi Michele: I really appreciate your response.  You also had a large tumor.  One of the things that has been an issue for me has been how did I not notice this mass until it was so large?  Even though my mother had breast cancer, I neglected doing BSE. Thank you for sharing your experience with hair loss including eyelashes and eyebrows.  Like most women I suppose, my hair has been part of my identity -- in my case since high school when I had near waist-long blonde "Marcia Brady" hair (I'm 51 so perhaps you can't relate to that era since you're so much younger).  One of the 2 women undergoing tx I've been in touch with chose to shave off her hair so she wouldn't wake up with it all over her pillow. As you said, the emotional impact can be difficult.  Being single,never married with no kids, I have a pattern of trying to bear my own emotional burdens, but I am realizing this one is too much for me to bear alone.  Because I have been on an emotional roller coaster since being diagnosed, I know that I need support from other women who understand -- both online and in person. Glad to hear how well you are doing.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and don't know how to navigate this site NewportLori xpectmiracles

Posts.Content: NewportLori wrote: My first post.  Although I received the results of my core biopsy 33 days ago, I have not yet had any treatment but have had a lot of follow-up tests to further define my specific disease.  My oncologist and surgeon have just agreed that neoadjuvant chemotherapy is probably best in my situation.  My onc would use the TC regimen.  I have many questions and just discovered this site while searching for info on cold cap therapy to prevent or reduce chemo hair loss.  I would like to participate here both to obtain information and to help others by sharing what I have learned or will learn in the future.  However, navigating the discussion topics and even how to see the most recent posts vs. original posts is confusing to me.  Is there an instruction manual somewhere? :) In the last month I have found that there is at least one silver lining in having this life-threatening disease -- that is the loving support and cameraderie from 2 other women also afflicted who are a bit ahead of me in treatment.  I've been in a bit of denial about the emotional impact and haven't yet joined any support groups either online or in person, but as it comes time to begin treatment, I am realizing how much I need a support network. Thanks for any navigation or other assistance. Lori Dx 5/28/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIB, Grade 2, 3/4 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and don't know how to navigate this site NewportLori xpectmiracles

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2009 11:23PM NewportLori wrote: Hi Lisa, I am being treated by physicians associated with Hoag Hospital in Newport Beach.  Although Hoag has a dedicated Breast Care Center, because I have an HMO (Blue Shield Access Plus) with Greater Newport Physicians as my IPA, I am not able to go to any of the surgeons or oncologists who are part of Hoag's BCC as none of them are part of the GNP IPA.  For most of my career prior to my recent focus on real estate, I was in either hospital administration or management consulting to hospitals and healthcare organizations.  I have an MPH in Health Services Management from UCLA.  In my opinion, it is a shame that the 100,000 HMO patients capitated to GNP do not have access to any of Hoag's BCC surgeons or oncologists.  Fortunately, the GNP surgeon to whom I was referred seems to be very well qualified. Additionally, the plastic surgeon to whom I was referred and who is part of my HMO network also seems to be well qualified.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed and don't know how to navigate this site NewportLori xpectmiracles

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 02:14PM NewportLori wrote: I started chemo 2 days ago on 7/24/09 -- TC every 3 wks X 6.  So far, no serious SE!  Some fatigue but I was sleep-deprived going into it.  Twinges of nausea just remind me to put something in my tummy and it goes away.  I am taking Emend and Zofran and have Compazine I can take if needed (so far not needed).  I am also taking prophylactic Prilosec recommended by onc RN.   May be becomming constipated so will try Miralax.  Taste buds slightly affected, but not too bad. My bigger concern is the potential bone pain from the Neulasta injection I am scheduled to get tomorrow.  I already have joint and spinal disk problems so am at higher risk for bone pain.  Onc RN suggests ibuprofen as first line of attack (bettern than Tylenol for this in her op).  I have read that Claritin (the allergy med) can also help, so will take prophylactically.  Heavier pain med can be called in if I need it. I just bought some generic Biotene mouth wash but haven't used.  I'm thinking this is so important that I should return it and get the real deal. I haven't had a chance to read all of the responses and look forward to learning a lot more.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 04:42PM - edited Jul 26, 2009 04:57PM by NewportLori Thanks for the welcome o2bhealthy.  As I am catching up on the posts, I am finding so much info and encouragement.  I really feel that all of this is going to be very manageable.  I am trying the Pengin Cold Caps to see if I can keep my hair, but it not, can deal with that too.  I already have a wig and scarves just in case. Best wishes to all.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 11:42PM - edited Jul 30, 2009 11:43PM by NewportLori Hi fellow triple J's: Day 6 post 1st tx.  Yesterday and today I did not feel quite as well as the previous days -- mainly body aches, fatigue and general maliase.  I have no appetite or hunger at all so don't even notice when I don't eat.  My mood is also a bit more depressed.  Yesterday evening I realized I hadn't eaten much all day and then ate too much for so late in the day.  Today is kind of the same thing -- I didn't eat anything at all until mid afternoon.  There is no pleasure in food right now as I can barely taste anything and the empty belly "feed me" sensation that I used to get if I skipped a meal seems on the fritz.  I believe we all have to eat sufficiently to keep our blood counts up so I'm going to try to look at food in the same way I look at the meds I have to take. Although we all react differently, it seems this taste malfunction thing is pretty common.  I'd like to ask what foods some of you are finding most palatable.  There's also probably a specific thread for eating while undergoing chemo.  I'll look for it. Very best wishes to all my BC sisters!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2009 02:06PM - edited Jul 31, 2009 02:09PM by NewportLori Regarding steriods... I think one of the reasons there may be some difference as to onc's recommendations for taking them beyond what is in the IV on the day of Tx could be due to which regimen we are on.  I'm on TC and the onc RN told me that the primary reason they have me take the steriod orally on the day before and two days after tx is to prevent edema -- particularly pulmonary edema, which can require hospitalization.  The anti-nausea effect is the secondary reason for giving it.  Edema is a known SE of Taxotere.  Perhaps the same concern does not exist with Adriamycin.  Just a thought.  I'm exhausted today.  Had pretty severe bone pain in the middle of the night when I didn't keep up with my ibuprofen (thought I didn't need it -- WRONG!).  I'm going to get some Alieve today as it lasts longer than ibup.  Once you get pain, it takes so much more to knock it down rather than prevent it. Hope we all have a SE free (or at least minimal) weekend.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2009 09:28PM NewportLori wrote: Just have to share that my taste buds are back!!!  I celebrated with a steak on the BBQ for dinner and even though it ended up overly well done, it tasted great!!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 12:06AM NewportLori wrote: Gill... Sorry to hear that your mouth is sore today,  I know exactily what you mean about cardboard corn though,  For a few days everything I ate seemed to taste like cardboard.  Because my tongue felt swollen and fuzzy, food was actually unpleasant and I was having a hard time eating.  When I woke up this moring, I realized that my tongue was returning to normal.  I savored my coffee and enjoyed every morsel I ate that tasted as it usually does.  Now I know what to expect in my next chemo cycle   There will be a few days of tongue fuzzies where eating may be unpleasant, but I will be well stocked with soups, deli meats and other items that I found to be palatable during this cycle.  In the meantime, I have a new appreciation for taste buds!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2009 08:08PM NewportLori wrote: Hi Triple J's: I'm on day 4 after my first of 6 scheduled TC txs and feel quite well.  Because my chemo was on Friday, I had to go back yesterday to learn how to give myself the Neulasta injection (wow, was that a painless shot!).  I took Claritin and Advil before the injection and again today and so far, no bone pain.  I feel very blessed that I am doing so well at this point.  My most pervasive SE is that my taste buds feel fried/numb all the time.  I see a lot of women have this SE.  Does it last all throughout chemo or does it wane a bit before the next tx? Because I haven't yet had surgery (I'm doing chemo first), it was great to feel like the war against this hostile invader of my body is finally on.  Get ready for shock and awe BC!!!  We've got chemical weapons and you are toast!!! Best wishes to all the other active warriors against BC!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in July 2009 PauldingMom jacee
